7:["$","section",null,{"className":"py-16","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"container mx-auto px-4","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"max-w-3xl mx-auto","children":[["$","h2",null,{"className":"text-3xl font-bold mb-6","children":["Living in ","Núñez"]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-lg max-w-none text-muted-foreground leading-relaxed","children":[["$","p","0",{"className":"mb-4","children":["Núñez is the last stop on the D line before Buenos Aires ends, and that relative remoteness is exactly its appeal. The neighborhood offers something rare in BA: space. Streets are wider, buildings are lower, and you can actually see the sky","."]}],["$","p","1",{"className":"mb-4","children":["It's home to River Plate's Monumental stadium, the Ciudad Universitaria campus, and a growing cluster of modern apartment towers along Avenida del Libertador. For expats, Núñez represents excellent value — you get northern-zone safety and quality at rents 20-30% below Belgrano and 40-50% below Palermo. The neighborhood is particularly popular with families and professionals who work remotely and don't need to be in the center daily","."]}],["$","p","2",{"className":"mb-4","children":["The Costanera Norte waterfront is walking distance for jogging and cycling, and the weekend markets at the stadium area are lively. The main trade-off is the commute — 35-45 minutes by Subte to the city center, though Uber and taxis are cheap alternatives. The restaurant scene is limited but improving.",""]}]]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"mt-12","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6
